text:
KIRAN MAZUMDAR-SHAW: My first
big recombinant DNA product
was insulin.

You know, India was at
the epicenter of diabetes.

And I thought to myself, I
said, you know, why are we
importing all our insulin?

Why don't I try and make
recombinant human insulin?

And let's see, I've got
this DNA technology.

Why don't I apply it and
see if I can make insulin?

And I used a very proprietary
yeast system to make insulin.

SPEAKER: So can you
explain to people

who are not as well
versed in science, what's

the novelty in this approach
compared to Eli Lilly and Novo

and others who were in
the insulin business?

KIRAN MAZUMDAR-SHAW:
So Eli Lilly

uses a bacterial
system, E. coli.

And Novo uses a Saccharomyces
yeast to make insulin.

I used Pichia, which is a very
different yeast system, which

is a high-yielding
yeast system, which
I use then to make insulin.

SPEAKER: And the intuition
was yours or your scientists,

that this approach
would be successful

because of some past
experience in something?

KIRAN MAZUMDAR-SHAW: So we
were using Pichia fermentation
for making an enzyme.

We were making a [INAUDIBLE]
enzyme using Pichia yeast.

It was a very
high-yielding process.
It was a very elegant process.

And we said, hey, if this
process can make insulin.
I think we're in business.

So we said, let's try and
see if we can actually

insert the insulin
gene into the Pichia

and see whether it
expresses the same way.
And we were lucky it did.

So we started making recombinant
human insulin using Pichia.
